column1: #Text=—The annual Ploughing Match for the premiums offered by the Bath and West of England Society, took place on Friday, the 7th inst., in a piece of old ley, in the occupation of Mr.

#Text=At half-post nine o’clock nineteen candidates were in the field, nine of whom had plough) drawn by two horses abreast without a driver, seven by three horses and a driver, and the other three by oxen.
#Text=As soon as each man had marked out his half acre and set in again, the whole started together by signal, at a quarter before twelve o’cclock.
#Text=The weather proved rather unfavourable, and there was not so large a concourse of persons attended as on a former occasion, in 1«26, when the last match took place in that neighbourhood.
#Text=When the ploughmen had all finished their work, the committee and a large party of gentlemen repaired to the Fleece Inn, Cirencester, where an excellent dinner was provided by Mr.
#Text=Richard Spooner, Esq., took the chair, and was supported by Lord Sherborne, the Hon.
#Text=Cripps, Esq., M.P., and between seventy and eighty agriculturists,several of whom came out of Worcestershire in compliment to Mr.
#Text=Spooner, knowing he was to lake the chair.
